head.headtext: Declarations against pecuniary or penal interest

para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-8-804(b)(3) provides that a statement against pecuniary or penal interest shall not be excluded by the hearsay rule if the declarant is unavailable as a witness. Such a statement is against interest if a reasonable person would have only made the statement if the declarant believed it to be true because, when made, it was so contrary to the declarant's pecuniary interest or exposed the declarant to civil or criminal liability. For such statements to be used in criminal cases to expose the declarant to criminal liability, there must be corroborating circumstances that clearly indicate its trustworthiness. The rule is equivalent to Fed. R. Evid. 804.

Prior to 2013, Georgia law did not recognize an exception for statements against penal interest in criminal cases.[1] The declaration against interest must have been against the proprietary or pecuniary interest[2] of the declarant, such as financial loss,[3] disparagement of his title,[4] or against his right to recover in tort or concerning his tort liability.[5] This change aligns the Georgia rule with the much broader federal rule and applies to a statement offered in a criminal case if it “tends to expose the declarant to criminal liability.”

The federal rule was amended in 2010 to specifically provide that the corroborating circumstances requirement applies to all declarations against penal interest offered in criminal cases because, as The Advisory Committee Notes explain, “[a] number of courts have applied the corroborating circumstances requirement to declarations against penal interest offered by the prosecution, even though the text of the Rule did not so provide.” The rule now ensures that there is a “unitary approach” to declarations against penal interest. In U.S. v. Alvarez,[6] the United States Court held that, “by transplanting the language governing exculpatory statements onto the analysis for admitting inculpatory hearsay, a unitary standard is derived which offers the most workable basis for applying Rule 804(b)(3).”
The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit required corroborating circumstances for against-penal-interest statements offered by the government in U.S. v. Shukri.[7]

Both Fed. R. Evid. 804(a) and Georgia Rule 804(a) recognize that witnesses may be unavailable for circumstances other than death, such as when the declarant claims privilege, refuses to testify, testifies to a lack of memory about the subject matter, or is absent from trial because of death, illness, or infirmity or the proponent of the testimony is unable to procure the declarant's attendance by process or other reasonable means.[8]

In Hurt v. State,[9] the Georgia Supreme Court held admissible, under an admission against interest exception, a recorded telephone conversation with a witness, where the witness described the defendant's confession to him.
Jackson v. State, 288 Ga. 213, 215, 702 S.E.2d 201, 204 (2010) (statements against penal interest admissible when made to close family members).
Martin v. Turner, 235 Ga. 35, 218 S.E.2d 789 (1975); Miller v. Everett, 192 Ga. 26, 14 S.E.2d 449 (1941).
Lamar v. Pearre, 90 Ga. 377, 17 S.E. 92 (1892); Freeman v. Saxton, 240 Ga. 309, 240 S.E.2d 708 (1977).
Barbre v. Scott, 75 Ga. App. 524, 43 S.E.2d 760 (1947).
U.S. v. Shukri, 207 F.3d 412, 53 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 737 (7th Cir. 2000).

Obviously, a declarant is not unavailable as a witness if “the declarant's exemption, refusal, claim of lack of memory, inability, or absence is due to the procurement or wrongdoing of the proponent of a statement for the purpose of preventing the witness from attending or testifying.” Fed. R. Evid. 804(a)(5); O.C.G.A. § 24-8-804(a).
